title: Cancer and Aging Research Group Chemotherapy Toxicity Tool (CARG-TT)
description: The CARG-TT estimates the risk of severe chemotherapy-related side effects (Grade 3 or greater toxicity) in older cancer patients (age >65). It uses 11 geriatric assessment variables, laboratory values, and patient characteristics to predict chemotherapy toxicity risk.

parameters.name: hearing_impaired
parameters.description: Hearing fair, poor, or totally deaf (vs. excellent/good)

parameters.name: falls_past_6_months
parameters.description: History of falls in the preceding 6 months

parameters.name: walking_limited
parameters.description: Limited in walking one block or more

parameters.name: social_activity_decreased
parameters.description: Decreased social activity because of health

ranges.interpretation: Low risk of severe chemotherapy toxicity. Standard chemotherapy regimens can generally be considered. Monitor closely for side effects and provide supportive care as needed.
Intermediate risk of severe chemotherapy toxicity. Consider dose reduction, alternative regimens, or enhanced supportive care measures. Close monitoring and frequent follow-up recommended.

High risk of severe chemotherapy toxicity. Strongly consider dose reduction, single-agent therapy, or alternative treatment approaches. Intensive supportive care and very frequent monitoring essential.

references: Hurria A, Togawa K, Mohile SG, Owusu C, Klepin HD, Gross CP, et al. Predicting chemotherapy toxicity in older adults with cancer: a prospective multicenter study. J Clin Oncol. 2011 Sep 1;29(25):3457-65. doi: 10.1200/JCO.2011.34.7625.

Magnuson A, Sattar S, Nightingale G, Saracino R, Skoneczka J, Trevino KM, et al. A practical guide to geriatric syndromes in older adults with cancer: A focus on falls, cognition, polypharmacy, and depression. Am Soc Clin Oncol Educ Book. 2019 Jan;39:e96-e109. doi: 10.1200/EDBK_237641.

Extermann M, Boler I, Reich RR, Lyman GH, Brown RH, DeFelice J, et al. Predicting the risk of chemotherapy toxicity in older patients: the Chemotherapy Risk Assessment Scale for High-Age Patients (CRASH) score. Cancer. 2012 Jul 1;118(13):3377-86. doi: 10.1002/cncr.26646.
formula: Score = (2 × age_72_or_older) + (2 × gi_gu_cancer) + (2 × standard_dose_chemo) + (2 × polychemotherapy) + (3 × hemoglobin_low) + (3 × creatinine_clearance_low) + (2 × hearing_impaired) + (3 × falls_past_6_months) + (1 × medication_assistance) + (2 × walking_limited) + (1 × social_activity_decreased)
notes: Use in cancer patients aged 65 years or older undergoing chemotherapy
Hemoglobin thresholds: males <11 g/dL, females <10 g/dL
Creatinine clearance calculated using Cockcroft-Gault equation
Standard dose = 100% of published dose, reduced dose = <100%
Recommended by ASCO guidelines for geriatric oncology assessment
Based on prospective study of 500 patients aged ≥65 years
Grade ≥3 toxicity defined by Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events (CTCAE)
